lead_paragraph: Early in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s tenure, unions were among his biggest supporters. Now, with the possibility of a re-election fight looming, they are beginning to wonder if they should stick with him.

byline.original: By J. DAVID GOODMAN and WILLIAM NEUMAN

headline.print_headline: For Unions and City Hall, Close Relationship Grows More Complicated
headline.main: For Unions and New York City Hall, an Open-Door Relationship Turns Complex

snippet: Early in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s tenure, unions were among his biggest supporters. Now, with the possibility of a re-election fight looming, they are beginning to wonder if they should stick with him....
abstract: Good will between New York City labor unions and Mayor Bill de Blasio is threatened by several overlapping state and federal fund-raising investigations bringing unwanted scrutiny and potential problems; de Blasio’s approval numbers are below 50 percent and city’s powerful public and private unions are beginning to consider whether to stick with an embattled mayor in 2017 re-election bid or risk abandoning their long-time supporter to back a challenger.
